# ğŸ”¥ Introduction

### âœ… Key Features of ggplot2

1ï¸âƒ£ **Grammar of Graphics**: A structured approach to building visualizations using layer.

2ï¸âƒ£ **Aesthetic Mappings**: Define how data variables are mapped to visual properties.

3ï¸âƒ£ **Geometries**: Different plot types (bars, lines, points) to represent data effectively.

**ggplot2** is a powerful and flexible package in R for data visualization. It is based on the **grammar of graphics** and provides a systematic way to create complex plots with minimal code. This crash course covers the basics of ggplot2, including color usage with the **colorspace** package. ğŸš€

If you're new to data visualization in R, **ggplot2** is the best place to start! With its intuitive syntax, it allows you to create stunning and customizable plots effortlessly. This tutorial is designed for **first-time learners** and will walk you through the fundamental concepts step by step. By the end, you'll be comfortable creating a variety of plots with beautiful color palettes. ğŸ¨ğŸ“Š

# ğŸ”§ Installation and Setup

To get started, install **ggplot2** and **colorspace** if you havenâ€™t already:

```{r}
install.packages("ggplot2")
install.packages("colorspace")
```

Then load the necessary packages:

```{r}
library(ggplot2)
library(colorspace)
```

# ğŸ“Š Creating a Sample Data Frame

We'll create a simple dataset for visualization:

```{r}
data <- tibble::tibble(
  category = rep(c("A", "B", "C", "D"), each = 10),
  value = rnorm(40, mean = 50, sd = 10),
  time = rep(1:10, times = 4)
)

data
```

# ğŸ—ï¸ Basic ggplot Structure

A basic **ggplot** consists of: âœ… `ggplot(data, aes(x, y))` - Define the data and aesthetics âœ… A `geom_*()` function - Specify the plot type âœ… Additional customization layers

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## ğŸ“‰ Bar Plot ğŸ“¦

```{r}
ggplot(data, aes(x = category, fill = category)) +
  geom_bar() +
  scale_fill_discrete_divergingx() +
  theme_classic()
```

## ğŸ¯ Scatter Plot ğŸ”µ

```{r}
ggplot(data, aes(x = value, y = time, color = value)) +
  geom_point(size = 4) +
  scale_color_continuous_sequential(palette = "Inferno") +
  theme_light()
```

## ğŸ“ˆ Line Plot ğŸ“Œ

```{r}
ggplot(data, aes(x = time, y = value, group = category, color = category)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.2) +
  scale_color_discrete_diverging(palette = "Blue-Red 3") +
  theme_minimal()
```

## ğŸ“¦ Box Plot ğŸ

```{r}
ggplot(data, aes(x = category, y = value, fill = category)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  scale_fill_discrete_sequential(palette = "Plasma") +
  theme_minimal()
```

------------------------------------------------------------------------

# ğŸ·ï¸ Customizing Titles and Labels ğŸ·ï¸

Adding titles, subtitles, captions, and axis labels enhances the clarity of your plots. ğŸ¯

### ğŸ“ Adding Titles & Labels

```{r}
ggplot(data, aes(x = category, y = value, fill = category)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  labs(title = "Category-wise Value Distribution",
       subtitle = "A bar plot with custom colors",
       x = "Category",
       y = "Value",
       caption = "Source: Simulated Data") +
  theme_minimal()
```

### ğŸ¨ Customizing Theme & Labels

```{r}
ggplot(data, aes(x = value, y = time, color = category)) +
  geom_point(size = 4) +
  labs(title = "Scatter Plot of Value vs. Time",
       x = "Value",
       y = "Time",
       color = "Category") +
  theme_light()
```

------------------------------------------------------------------------

# ğŸ¨ Customizing Colors ğŸ¨

## ğŸ¨ Using `scale_fill_manual()` ğŸ¨

âœ… Define custom colors for bars:

```{r}
ggplot(data, aes(x = category, y = value, fill = category)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("A" = "#1b9e77", "B" = "#d95f02", "C" = "#7570b3", "D" = "#e7298a")) +
  theme_minimal()
```

## ğŸ¨ Using `scale_color_manual()` ğŸ¨

âœ… Define custom colors for points:

```{r}
ggplot(data, aes(x = value, y = time, color = category)) +
  geom_point(size = 4) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("A" = "#e41a1c", "B" = "#377eb8", "C" = "#4daf4a", "D" = "#984ea3")) +
  theme_light()
```

## ğŸŒˆ Using Colors from `colorspace` ğŸŒˆ

âœ… Apply beautiful color palettes with **colorspace**:

```{r}
ggplot(data, aes(x = category, fill = category)) +
  geom_bar() +
  scale_fill_discrete_sequential(palette = "SunsetDark") +
  theme_classic()
```
